) As the administrators of our nation’s tax system, our dedication to the standards of ethical behavior and conduct promotes the public trust in our honesty, fairness and efficiency. Therefore, IRS employees are expected fully comply with all tax laws by accurately reporting and timely ﬁling their federal, state, and local tax returns and fully paying their taxes when due. includes paying the proper amount of tax (e.g., estimated tax payments withholding) as income is earned during the tax year. RRA
sections
) and (b)(

) provide for the removal of IRS employees who fail to ﬁle any return of tax required under the Internal Revenue Code of on or before the date prescribed therefore, or who willfully understate tax liability respectively. To this end, the IRS has established a employee tax compliance program. Employees’ accounts will be examination, underreporter, and annual delinquency check procedures. (
) Each area has an employee audit coordinator. The employeeaudit is located in the area Planning and Special Programs (PSP) office. A list
Each area has an employee audit coordinator. The employeeaudit coordinator is located in the area Planning and Special Programs (PSP) office. A list of co-
ordinators may be found at the Employee Audit Contacts menu on the following website: http://mysbse.web.irs.gov/exam/tip/emplaudit/contacts/ default.aspx. IRM
, Policy Statement

, Highest Integrity Expected, provides standard IRS procedures relating to examinations, proposed changes, rights, etc., will apply to IRS employees to the same extent they apply to other taxpayers. Examination of employee returns are generally in six categories: • New employee examinations • Current employees who have not previously held an auditable and who are newly hired into an auditable position • Regularly classiﬁed employee examinations (returns that are under regular circumstances, such as DIF, but happen to be an employee) • Executive selections • Treasury mandated audits • Special projects to address identiﬁed employee compliance Examiners should review Form
, Examination Return Charge-Out on every case ﬁle to determine if it reﬂects the words “Employee Return.” designation can be found about one third of the way down from the top of Form
If Form
is not in the case ﬁle, the examiner should and review IMFOLI to check for an IRS employee indicator. See Exhibit

) If a return has not been pre-identiﬁed as an employee return and it is found to be an employee return after further inspection/examination, the examiner must notify their group manager as soon as possible. The group manager will determine whether the examiner may proceed with examining the return or whether it should be reassigned. The words “employee return” should be
General Examining written at the top of the Form
or the IMFOLI (when no Form
is the case ﬁle). The examiner must document actions taken on Form
, Examining Officer’s Activity Record. (
) Conversely, if a return has been pre-identiﬁed as an employee audit and individual is no longer employed with IRS, follow the procedures in IRM

) Examiners must ensure impartiality and independence when examining an employee return. If examiners have any reason to believe that their and independence may be questioned, they should discuss the matter with their immediate supervisor for reassignment consideration. (
) The impartial and independent character of examinations of IRS employees and officials must be ensured. See IRM
, Employee Audits, for lines on assignment of employee returns for examination. (
) Employee audits are high priority cases and should be assigned within
business days of arrival into the group. (

) When an examiner is assigned an employee return for examination and the employee is located in another post-of-duty, the examiner is authorized to to the travel to the employee’s business, residence, or other location where the books and records are maintained. All travel costs will be borne by the examining area. (

) An examination of an employee generally should be worked as a normal amination. The employee under examination should not be given treatment nor should the employee be held to a higher standard than any taxpayer under examination. (
) Normal pre-contact responsibilities apply to an employee audit. The should use current risk based decision tools in any decision to adjust the scope of the examination. See IRM
, Pre-Contact Responsibilities. (
) Normal required ﬁling checks apply to an employee audit. See IRM
, Required Filing Checks. (

) Employee audits are very sensitive and require certain modiﬁcations to the amination process. The following modiﬁcations must be made: a. The examiner should use the normal and appropriate initial letter to begin the examination. See IRM
for employee procedures. b. The examiner should include Form
, Employee Notiﬁcation Regarding Union Representation, with the initial contact letter bargaining unit employees and attempt to secure a signed copy the initial interview takes place. The Form

) The employee audit website is located at emplaudit/default.aspx. (

) The return of an employee’s spouse who has ﬁled separately should be inspected as part of the required ﬁling checks to determine if it should be of Spouse’s examined. A copy, RTVUE, or CDE print of the spouse’s return must be Return included with the employee’s return if it is not examined. See IRM Key Points for Reviews. (
) If the spouse’s return is examined, each Form
, Special Handling for Examination Case Processing, should be cross referenced with the taxpayer identiﬁcation number (TIN) of the related return. (
) If facts are disclosed during the examination that indicate an employee have engaged in any activity in violation of the rules of employee of the Code of examiner should refer to Document
, Internal Revenue Service Handbook, and consult with his or her manager. (
) Current civil and criminal fraud procedures will be followed, where See IRM

, Fraud Handbook. Certain fraud technical advisors (FTA) been designated to assist with employee examinations. The FTA should identiﬁed in the packet that accompanied the case ﬁle. If no information available, contact the manager of FTA Group
or the area’s employee coordinator. (
) If a joint investigation is initiated with Criminal Investigation on an audit, the examiner should immediately contact the Field Exam General Processes analyst at: Employee Audits - Contacts. (

) Labor/employee relations (LR/ER) specialists will occasionally request an update on the audit status. Their request should be directed as follows: with a. If the case was recently closed from the group and sent for review, the LR/ER specialist should contact the Baltimore Technical Services group manager. b. If the case is assigned to an examination group, the LR/ER should contact the group manager. (

) The group manager should decide whether to retain the case and work it or survey it using survey procedures. See IRM
below for additional The case will no longer be considered high priority. (
) Current employees newly hired into auditable positions and new employees auditable positions must undergo employee tax return reviews or or both. (
) The employee audit coordinator establishes controls on employee examina- tions and builds the case ﬁle. (

) The package sent to the group should contain the following items: • Return(s) (original, copy, RTVUE, or CDE print) and • CFOL reports of account history for the open years and information return processing (IRP) transcripts. (
) Employee returns will be examined in the same manner as all individual income tax returns, which include conducting minimum income probes and required ﬁling checks. (

) If the primary reason for the examination of a new employee’s return is eration for employment and the individual is no longer employed by IRS or no longer being considered for employment, the examiner must discuss the scope of this case with his or her group manager. See IRM

) The initial interview in an employee tax audit has increased signiﬁcance, as outcome of the examination may initiate a conduct investigation. The er’s interview questions should adequately probe the employee’s role in preparation of the return, participation in any businesses, investments, producing activities, and the employee’s role in identifying expenses or ments to income. (03-04-2013) Employee Interview Procedures

The examiner should provide the employee with a copy of Form 8111, Employee Notiﬁcation Regarding Union Representation, with the initial contact letter, discuss Form 8111 before conducting the initial interview,
and request the employee sign Form
to acknowledge notiﬁcation of his or her contractual rights. If the employee does not provide a signed Form
, the examiner will notate “Discussed and Solicited a Signed Form
—Employee Did Not Provide Signed Form
” on Form and proceed with the interview. The interview should not be delayed in order to secure a signed copy of Form

The examination should not be unreasonably delayed to secure union representation. An IRS employee is barred from appearing on behalf of any taxpayer as a representative before any federal, state, or local governmental agency, in an action involving a tax matter except on written authorization of the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, (
CFR
)). A union rep- resentative may be present and represent the employee in a conduct issue.
resentative may be present and represent the employee in a conduct issue. (
) Employee Attendance at the Audit: IRC
(c) generally prohibits IRS from requiring a taxpayer to accompany the taxpayer’s recognized representative an audit in the absence of an administrative summons. However, IRC provides that IRC

(c) shall not apply to investigations relating to the integrity of any officer or employee of the IRS. Since an audit of an relates to the integrity of the employee and may result in a disciplinary or adverse action against the employee, the employee’s recognized representa- tive may not attend the audit in lieu of the employee, although the representative may accompany the employee to the audit. Note: A recognized representative is any attorney, certiﬁed public accountant, enrolled agent, enrolled actuary, or any other person permitted to that taxpayer before the IRS who is not disbarred or suspended from practice before the IRS and who has a written power of attorney executed the taxpayer. (
) An employee will be granted administrative leave to attend a tax audit or a cussion of the employee’s own tax affairs. (
) An employee will not be granted administrative leave to prepare for an nation. (
) Survey procedures are applicable only to new employee examinations and regularly classiﬁed returns. Treasury mandates (TIGTA referrals) and selections cases cannot be surveyed. (

) Once an IRS employee’s return has been selected for examination and assigned to a group, it can only be surveyed with written approval. This action must include a description of any documents and or other information used to draw this conclusion. Surveys are subject to mandatory review. See IRM
, Delegation Order
(formerly DO-
, Rev.
), IRS Employees’ Returns Selected for Examination, for the appropriate approving official. (

) When an examiner believes that an examination of an employee’s return result in no material change in tax liability, he or she may apply survey after assignment procedures. The examiner will prepare a Form

, Income Tax Survey After Assignment, stating the reasons for the survey action. If the ex- aminer’s group manager concurs, he or she will approve the case and it to the Territory Manager for his or her consideration and ﬁnal approval on
Employee Attendance at the Audit: IRC
(c) generally prohibits IRS from requiring a taxpayer to accompany the taxpayer’s recognized representative to an audit in the absence of an administrative summons. However, IRC
(d) provides that IRC

(c) shall not apply to investigations relating to the integrity of any officer or employee of the IRS. Since an audit of an employee relates to the integrity of the employee and may result in a disciplinary or adverse action against the employee, the employee’s recognized representa- tive may not attend the audit in lieu of the employee, although the recognized representative may accompany the employee to the audit.
(03-04-2013) Survey of Employee Returns

Once an IRS employee’s return has been selected for examination and assigned to a group, it can only be surveyed with written approval. This action must include a description of any documents and or other information used to draw this conclusion. Surveys are subject to mandatory review. See IRM 1.2.43.34, Delegation Order 4-40 (formerly DO-244, Rev. 1), IRS Employees’ Returns Selected for Examination, for the appropriate approving

) Check the “Employee Audit” box on Form
, Special Handling Notice for Examination Case Processing, in the “Forward to Technical Service” section, when closing the case. (
) All employee audits are mandatory review, thus the “Employee Audits” box the “Forward to Technical Services” section of Form
, Special Handling Notice for Examination Case Processing, must always be checked of the type of closure (this includes surveys). (

) All employee audit returns are subject to mandatory review and must be closed directly to the Employee Audit Reviewer in Baltimore Technical Services. ) In the case of a joint return, identify the name and social security number (SSN) of the IRS employee on Form
by checking the “other” block in the “Forward to Technical Services” section and notate the name and SSN of the employee on the lines provided. (
) Baltimore Technical Services will close the case to the appropriate Centralized Case Processing (CCP) office. (

) Once the case is closed from Baltimore Technical Services, CCP will forward the required employee audit information in the case ﬁle to the requesting offi- cial such as Labor/Employee Relations, Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration (TIGTA), or IRS Personnel Security.
) An employee may avail themselves of the audit reconsideration process. to IRM
, Audit Reconsiderations, for information concerning the audit consideration process and procedures. (

) Employee audit reconsideration cases that are selected will be sent to the propriate area PSP office for assignment and control. The case should be returned to the group and examiner that originally worked the case. audit reconsideration cases are high priority cases. They are given the priority status as employee audit cases. (
) The purpose of the audit reconsideration is to examine information that was not previously considered. The examiner should review IRM
, Area Office (AO) Examination Group Procedures, for guidance and procedures examining and closing an audit reconsideration case.

The purpose of the audit reconsideration is to examine information that was not previously considered. The examiner should review IRM 4.13.4.3, Area Office (AO) Examination Group Procedures, for guidance and procedures for examining and closing an audit reconsideration case.
